qas.question: What did SPECTRE originally stand for?

answers.text: SPecial Executive for Counter-intelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion

qas.question: Who fought over the movie rights for Thunderball?
In what year did McClory and Fleming reach an agreement?
Which movie was a modern version of Thunderball?
What was the name of a proposed remake of Thunderball that was never made?
In what year did Fleming settle with McClory?
What was the name of the remake of Thunderball?
Which Bond novel first featured Spectre?
What organization has faced litigation issues since 1981?
Who incorporated elements of an undeveloped film script written by Saltzman into Thuderball?
Who became a producer on the 1985 film Thunderball?
What was planned for release in the 1980s but then abandoned?

context: The ownership of the <b8_0>Spectre<b8_0/> organisation—originally stylised "SPECTRE" as an acronym of <a0_0>SPecial Executive for Counter-intelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion<a0_0/>—and its characters, had been at the centre of long-standing litigation starting in 1961 between <a1_0>Ian Fleming and Kevin McClory<a1_0/> over the film rights to the novel <a7_0>Thunderball.<a7_0/> The dispute began after <b9_0>Fleming<b9_0/> incorporated elements of an undeveloped film script written by McClory and screenwriter Jack Whittingham—including characters and plot points—into Thunderball, which McClory contested in court, claiming ownership over elements of the novel. In <a2_0><a5_0>1963<a5_0/><a2_0/>, Fleming settled out of court with McClory, in an agreement which awarded <b10_0>McClory<b10_0/> the film rights. This enabled him to become a producer for the 1965 film Thunderball—with Albert R. Broccoli and Harry Saltzman as executive producers—and the non-Eon film <a3_0><a6_0>Never Say Never Again<a6_0/><a3_0/>, an updated remake of Thunderball, in 1983.[N 3] A second remake, entitled <a4_0><b11_0>Warhead 2000 A.D.<b11_0/><a4_0/>, was planned for production and release in the 1990s before being abandoned. Under the terms of the 1963 settlement, the literary rights stayed with Fleming, allowing the Spectre organisation and associated characters to continue appearing in print.
